Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Molecular Simulation of DNA Interactions in Oligonucleotide Microarrays

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The hybridization and denaturation transitions between single- and doubled-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) will be studied for short oligomers, between 10 and 25 bases, both in solution and with one strand bound to a surface to determine how surface immobilization affects this equilibrium and the interactions between strands. The aspects of this project explore the differences between surface- and solution-based transitions for systems that are most pertinent to DNA microarray technology. These aspects include surface density of DNA molecules, length of the molecule and complementarity of the sequence.

Nontechnical
This proposal will help better determine the rules governing formation of double stranded DNA complexes. Formation of such doubled stranded DNA complexes is used in genomics to understand levels of gene expression and also in medical diagnostics and food safety analyses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
DNA microarray sensors are a powerful technology that allow the rapid detection of specific DNA sequences.  In medical applications, a positive result can indicate cancer-causing mutations or other disease conditions; other applications can include identifying the presence of pathogenic bacteria or viruses.  Consisting of single-stranded DNA bound to a surface, if a test sample contains the target DNA sequence it will form a perfectly complementary double helix with the surface-bound strand and be subsequently detected. Often, however, binding one DNA strand to a surface alters the properties of the double helix in unexpected ways and which are difficult to study experimentally.  This necessitates extensive initial calibration and reliability testing of new microarrays.  This project has focused on using molecular simulation to carry out computational studies of model DNA microarrays, and provided microscopic insight into the impact of surface binding on DNA double helices.  Many variables were studied including sequence, strand length, surface strand density, and surface binding motif.  As expected, both surface binding and increased surface strand density lead to slight destabilization.  Significantly, results also indicate that surface-bound strands have decreased double helix interactions at the surface-bound end but enhanced interactions at the far end.  While destabilization is related to elongation of the surface-bound end and increased fraying of the double helix, on the other hand the enhanced interactions correspond to reduced fraying.  These results suggest that the design of DNA microarrays can be improved in several ways.  First, taking into account differences in surface-bound versus far end interactions will allow more accurate predictions of double helix stability.  Additionally, false-positive detection signals can be reduced by avoiding surface-bound sequences where the far end is complementary to non-target regions in likely analysis samples, or if unavoidable can be taken into account during analysis of results.  Improvements along these lines would ideally lead to reduced initial reliability testing and increase robustness of DNA microarray technology.  This project has also provided opportunities for undergraduate students to be involved in all steps of the scientific research process.  From initial study of the topic to carrying out calculations and data analysis to presentation and publication of results to the scientific community, students have gained valuable first hand training and experience that will prepare them for their future.
